comments.author: Sobachatina
comments.content: That looks quite delicious. So... How was it? I assume the flavor of the freekeh is grassy and smokey? How was the texture?

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: I really liked it! You do get hints of grass and smoke, not real agressive but present. The texture is toothsome and pleasing. Not exactly like a meat meatball, but nice on its own terms.

comments.author: Carol
comments.content: Hmmm.. never heard of Freekeh before! Sounds interesting. The recipe looks yummy, I will have to try it out. :)

comments.author: Zia Elle
comments.content: Never seen and hear about it before. But I'm so curiose, I'll go around and look for this :) May be in an iranian grocery...

comments.author: janet @ the taste space
comments.content: This looks great! I wonder if I could use chia or flax instead of the eggs, though. Otherwise, I pretty much adore anything with pomegranate molasses. :) I haven't tried freekeh yet, but since I like wheat berries, I am sure I will love them too.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: The eggs are there for binding power, so something like NRG Egg Replacer might work as well.

comments.author: anna
comments.content: Hmmm...interesting! I love that it has probably loads of fiber for the digestive tract. Although the name sounds like freaky, I think this is great meatball (without the meat, that is!) Good job, chef!

comments.author: Rhean
comments.content: Freekeh sounds a lot like the German product, Grünkern (spelt picked green and then smoked), which I've been missing and unable to find locally. I'll see if I have any better luck finding freekeh.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Fascinating! That does sound like a very similar ingredient. You should get your hands on a boxcar and start retailing it, it could be the next big thing :).

comments.author: Catherine
comments.content: Funny - I just found a brand of freekeh (Greenwheat Freekeh) in Whole Foods in New Jersey.  Excellent source of fiber and has a low GI for managing diabetes.  If it's not available in stores near you - I researched it and you can find it @ freekehlicious.com

comments.author: foodie @ picyourtaste.com
comments.content: freekeh sounds really close to freaky :) ... definitely something new... and i love to try out new stuff... thanks for sharing

comments.author: RH
comments.content: So...  when do you add the eggplant?  I don't see that in the instructions anywhere.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Whoops! Fixed. Thanks for the sharp eyes.

comments.author: RH
comments.content: Thanks!  I actually made this for dinner tonight, but I'm gluten intolerant so I subbed a mix of toasted millet and buckwheat groats for the freekeh.  I'm sure it's not the same, but it was certainly delicious!  Served it with a side of braised tomatoes and beet greens with more ras al hanout & raisins.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Nice call on the substitutions! Buckwheat especially has a somewhat similar texture and an interesting flavor so I imagine that would work well. Glad you liked 'em.

comments.author: weirdcombos
comments.content:
These are very good looking polpetas. I have some freekeh in my pantry that's been sitting there for while now. Time to put it to use! Never had Ras El Hanout this spicemix looks good too.
Heguiberto

comments.author: claire
comments.content: I'm middle eastern- is freakah like cracked wheat? ever have cracked wheat?

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: The texture is similar if I remember cracked wheat right. It has been awhile. But freekeh has a unique flavor due to the greenness and roasting.

comments.author: Katherine Martinelli
comments.content: Is it weird that I have all of these ingredients on hand? I love freekeh but have only made it in pilafs and grain salads - this sounds awesome! I've bookmarked it to make soon.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Ah, a fellow odd-ingredient stockpiler. There should be a club for us.

comments.author: Lisa Holden
comments.content: I love Freekeh! I work for a natural foods company and we started carrying this earlier this year. I use it for everything. It's great as a hot cereal in the morning and a bed for stir fry. The possibilities are endless with this ingredient. I want to make a pudding with it next, like rice pudding.

comments.author: aleks
comments.content: for a food blogger u need to be more informed, freekeh is spelt, not weed

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freekeh

comments.author: Jemah
comments.content: Tried using Orgran Egg Replacer, but it did not bind. I ended up caving and putting in an egg instead. Was very tasty, however, next time I might even batter and crumb them in breadcrumbs just to add extra crunch.

comments.author: Demet
comments.content: Looks rich in flavour and texture! Never heard of freekeh but the kofte makes me think of bulgur kofte. There no egg is used but a finer grade of bulgur. I wonder, if freekeh is available also smaller/as powder, and whether that would bind better.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Hey Demet - I imagine finer would bind better, but I actually like the coarser texture, I think it better mimics the "fluffier" texture of a traditional meatball, possibly with breadcrumbs in it.
